channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 The New York Times Company

item.title: Mexican Cartels Lure Chemistry Students to Make Fentanyl
item.description: Criminals turn college campuses into recruitment hubs, recruiting chemistry students in Mexico with big paydays.
item.dc:creator: Natalie Kitroeff and Paulina Villegas
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.media:description: A 19-year-old sophomore chemistry major, who also works for the Sinaloa drug cartel, at a stash house.

item.title: 80 Years After Killings, Senegal Wants the Facts From France
item.description: The mass slaying of West African soldiers by colonial forces at the end of World War II in Senegal remains shrouded in secrecy. But Senegal’s new government won’t abide the mystery.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier and Saikou Jammeh
item.media:credit: Sylvain Cherkaoui for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Thiaroye military cemetery in Senegal has 35 graves representing West African soldiers that France said were killed by French Army soldiers in 1944. Historians said the actual death toll may be closer to 400.

item.title: Angola, the U.S. and a Slavery Connection Few Talk About
item.description: When President Biden visits the country this week, he is expected to highlight a largely overlooked bond between Angola and the United States that was born out of the trans-Atlantic slave trade.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon and Joao Silva
item.media:description: A view of the Cuanza River in Massangano, Angola. Enslaved Angolans were transported by boat along the Cuanza River.

item.title: Syria Rebels Take Aleppo Airport and Attack Hama, Officials and a Monitor Say
item.description: Forces opposed to President Bashar al-Assad have captured the Aleppo airport and are attacking the western city of Hama, according to local officials and a Britain-based war monitor.
item.dc:creator: Muhammad Haj Kadour and Vivian Yee
item.media:description: Rebel fighters with an abandoned Syrian government tank in the east of Aleppo Province on Sunday.

item.title: Former Defense Minister Accuses Israel of Committing War Crimes in Gaza
item.description: The comments by Moshe Yaalon were swiftly denied and condemned by allies of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel, who said that they would hurt the country and help its enemies.
item.dc:creator: Adam Rasgon, Liam Stack and Natan Odenheimer
item.media:credit: Dan Balilty for The New York Times
item.media:description: Moshe Yaalon, left, who was the Israeli defense minister from 2013 to 2016, with Benny Gantz, who later held that role, in Tel Aviv in 2019.

item.title: Ireland’s Main Parties Edge Out Sinn Féin, Early Election Results Show
item.description: At one level, the vote was an endorsement of continuity, but the stability in Ireland’s political center ground masked volatility on the fringes.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia and Mark Landler
item.media:credit: Paulo Nunes dos Santos for The New York Times
item.media:description: In Dublin and the rest of Ireland, economic concerns and anxiety about immigration were top electoral issues.

item.title: Protesters in Tbilisi Clash With Georgian Police
item.description: The government’s decision to suspend its bid for European Union membership has driven thousands of protesters into the streets.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins and Cassandra Vinograd
item.media:description: The police used water cannons and tear gas on Sunday in Tbilisi, Georgia, during a rally outside the Parliament building prompted by the government’s move to suspend negotiations on joining the European Union.

item.title: A Power Vacuum in Gaza Could Empower Warlords and Gangs
item.description: Hamas’s weakened position could leave the territory without any governing institutions.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.media:description: A picture taken during a tour organized by the Israeli Army shows a Palestinian truck arriving Saturday to pick up aid destined for the Gaza Strip from a drop-off area near the Kerem Shalom crossing.

item.title: France’s Government Under Prime Minister Michel Barnier Faces Week of Reckoning
item.description: The end of Michel Barnier’s government looks inevitable, even imminent, and would add to the country’s political malaise. The only question seems to be: How long can he last?
item.dc:creator: Adam Nossiter
item.media:credit: Julien De Rosa/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Prime Minister Michel Barnier of France after a cabinet meeting at the Élysée Palace in Paris last Wednesday.

item.title: Taiwan’s President Visits Pacific Islands to Counter China’s Influence
item.description: Lai Ching-te is looking to shore up support from three island nations that are among a dwindling number to keep diplomatic ties with Taiwan.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley and Amy Chang Chien
item.media:description: Lai Ching-te, the Taiwanese president, at Taoyuan International Airport, Taiwan, on Saturday. He is scheduled to visit the Marshall Islands, Tuvalu and Palau.

item.title: How Kennedy Has Worked Abroad to Weaken Global Public Health Policy
item.description: The health secretary pick and his organization have worked around the world to undermine longstanding policies on measles, AIDS and more.
item.dc:creator: Selam Gebrekidan, Justin Scheck, Sarah Hurtes and Pete McKenzie
item.media:credit: Uli Seit for The New York Times
item.media:description: Robert F. Kennedy Jr., an environmental lawyer, has spent years working abroad with organizations and associates that undermine longstanding global health policies, records show.

item.title: Israel Accuses World Central Kitchen Worker of Role in Oct. 7 Attack
item.description: The Israeli military said it killed the worker in a strike in Gaza on Saturday. “To the best of our knowledge, no WCK team members are affiliated with Hamas,” a spokeswoman for the aid group said.
item.dc:creator: Tim Balk
item.media:description: An Israeli airstrike damaged a vehicle carrying World Central Kitchen workers.

item.title: Russia Captures More Villages in Eastern Ukraine
item.description: Russian forces are closing in on two strongholds. The fall of the cities could pave the way for a takeover of the southern part of the Donetsk region, analysts said.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:description: Damaged buildings in Kurakhove, Ukraine, last month, in an area targeted by Russian strikes.

item.title: Clashes at Soccer Match Kill Dozens in Guinea
item.description: It was unclear on Sunday how many people were killed, but at least one estimate neared 100 people.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra E. Petri

item.title: Syria’s Rebels Struck When Assad’s Allies Were Weakened and Distracted
item.description: Diminished support for the Syrian government from Iran, Hezbollah and Russia enabled opposition forces to take the initiative and seize new territory.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim
item.media:credit: Omar Haj Kadour/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Opposition fighters loading ammunition onto a truck in northwestern Syria on Sunday.

item.title: Monday Briefing: Rebels Advance in Syria
item.description: Plus, the vast network of undersea internet cables.
item.dc:creator: Gaya Gupta
item.media:description: Anti-regime fighters near a road leading to Hama province.

item.title: Stowaway on Flight to Paris Disrupts a Return Flight to New York
item.description: The same passenger who stowed away on a Delta Air Lines flight to Paris caused a disturbance on a flight to New York on Saturday, an aviation official said.
item.dc:creator: Hank Sanders
item.media:description: The stowaway passenger who was caught on a Delta flight from New York to Paris days earlier was removed from a Paris to New York flight, also on Delta, after creating a disturbance on Saturday.

item.title: Nations Fail to Reach an Agreement on Plastic Pollution
item.description: Talks on the world’s first treaty to tackle plastic pollution will continue in coming months, delegates said.
item.dc:creator: Hiroko Tabuchi
item.media:description: The world produces nearly a half-billion tons of plastic each year, more than twice the amount produced two decades ago.

item.title: What a Marine Heat Wave Reveals About Our Warming Oceans
item.description: An extreme heat wave off California’s coast seemed like an anomaly 10 years ago. But as the ocean warms, the catastrophe may be a glimpse of the future.
item.dc:creator: Delger Erdenesanaa and Ian C. Bates
item.media:description: Rodeo Beach, Calif., one of the beaches that volunteers survey regularly for wildlife.

item.title: U.S. Condemns China’s Harsh Sentence for a Prominent Journalist
item.description: The sentencing of Dong Yuyu, a former Harvard Nieman fellow, signals that officials consider some exchanges between Chinese citizens and foreigners to be espionage.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong
item.category: Ministry of State Security of the People's Republic of China
item.media:description: Dong Yuyu is the most prominent journalist imprisoned in mainland China.

item.title: Saudi Arabia Leads Pushback Against Global Plastic Treaty
item.description: Delegates from more than 170 countries are working to salvage a treaty that would tackle the growing problem of plastic pollution.
item.dc:creator: Hiroko Tabuchi
item.media:description: An oil processing plant in Saudi Arabia, the world’s top oil exporter.

item.title: Israel Strikes Sites in Lebanon Amid Fragile Cease-Fire
item.description: As the truce appeared to largely hold, a deal appeared far away in Gaza, where an Israeli strike killed dozens, according to a rescue group.
item.dc:creator: Liam Stack
item.media:description: A man looked over damage in Tyre, Lebanon, on Friday.

item.title: Giving Love
item.description: The act of giving a gift is a vehicle for showing people how you feel. Here are tips to find the perfect present.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Morrill

item.title: For Canada, Trade Tumult From Trump’s Return Has Begun
item.description: While the president-elect says he will impose a 25 percent tariff on everything Canada exports, Trudeau remains confident about forestalling that outcome.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau leaving his hotel on Friday to meet President-elect Donald J. Trump.

item.title: Rebels Seize Control Over Most of Syria’s Largest City in Aleppo
item.description: The rapid advance on Aleppo came just four days into a surprise opposition offensive that is the most intense escalation in years in the civil war.
item.dc:creator: Muhammad Haj Kadour and Raja Abdulrahim
item.media:credit: Muhammad Haj Kadour/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: An opposition flag waves over a market square in central Aleppo, Syria, on Saturday.

item.title: Israel-Hezbollah Cease-Fire Rests on a Wobbly Linchpin: Lebanon’s Army
item.description: The Lebanese Army is tasked with ensuring that Hezbollah abides by the cease-fire. It has failed at that task before.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas
item.media:description: Members of the Lebanese Army at the site of an Israeli strike in central Beirut, earlier this month.

item.title: What Happens When Undersea Internet Cables Snap?
item.description: The internet is made up of hundreds of cables crossing the floors and the canyons of the earth’s oceans. So what happens when the cables snap? James Glanz, an investigative reporter for The New York Times, explains what could go wrong with subsea internet cables and how these cables get fixed.
item.dc:creator: James Glanz, Christina Shaman, James Surdam and Alexandra Ostasiewicz

item.title: Trudeau Meets With Trump at Mar- Amid Tariff Concerns
item.description: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada is the first foreign G7 leader to visit President-elect Donald J. Trump since the election. He is under pressure to persuade Mr. Trump to back down from his tariff threat.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Mark Walker
item.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Justin Trudeau, prime minister of Canada, leaving his hotel in West Palm Beach, Fla., on Friday to meet with President-elect Donald J. Trump.

item.title: Nigeria Boat Capsizes, Killing at Least 27
item.description: Rescuers were searching for survivors after the vessel, taking passengers to a food market, capsized along the River Niger, officials said.
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.media:credit: Olympia De Maismont/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The river Niger, pictured near Lokoja, Nigeria, last month.

item.title: Major Canadian News Outlets Sue OpenAI In New Copyright Case
item.description: A coalition of some of Canada’s biggest media companies is seeking billions of dollars in compensation for what they say is copyright infringement on their work through ChatGPT.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.media:description: The Canadian Broadcasting Corporation office in Toronto. It, along with other major news outlets, claims OpenAI is illegally using their content.

item.title: Chad Ends Longtime Military Partnership With France
item.description: The decision by Chad is another blow to what remained of France’s military influence in the troubled stretch of countries below the Sahara, where Russia’s influence has been growing.
item.dc:creator: Adam Nossiter
item.media:description: French and Chadian soldiers prepare to board a Chadian national army transport plane at Faya-Largeau airport in northern Chad in 2022.

item.title: Syria Rebels Reach Aleppo, in Biggest Advance in Years
item.description: A new assault on Syrian regime forces reached the major city, according to rebels and a war monitor. Government warplanes struck back at rebel territory.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim
item.media:description: Fighters fire at Syrian government troops on the outskirts of Aleppo on Friday.

item.title: FIFA Should Compensate Migrant Workers Injured Building Qatar World Cup, Report Says
item.description: An unpublished report on the soccer governing body’s responsibility for migrant workers recommends that it should compensate those harmed.
item.dc:creator: Tariq Panja
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Workers on the construction site of the Al-Wakrah Stadium, a FIFA World Cup venue, during its construction in 2018.

item.title: UK Lawmakers Vote to Legalize Assisted Dying After Emotional Debate
item.description: After an emotional debate, Parliament voted on Friday in favor of allowing assisted suicide for some terminally ill people in England and Wales.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Supporters of assisted dying campaigning outside Parliament on Friday. Lawmakers voted by 330 to 275 in favor of the new legislation after a five hour debate.

item.title: UK Transport Secretary Louise Haigh Resigns After Fraud Conviction Revealed
item.description: In the latest setback for Prime Minister Keir Starmer, Louise Haigh resigned from the cabinet Friday after admitting she pleaded guilty to a type of fraud in 2014.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Louise Haigh in London last month. As transport minister she oversaw one of the Labour Party’s flagship policies of bringing Britain’s troubled private rail network back into public ownership.

item.title: Protests Erupt in Georgia as It Pulls Back From Pro-Western Path
item.description: Thousands of people took to the streets after the government said it had suspended talks on joining the European Union.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: Riot police officers confronting protesters in Tbilisi, Georgia, early Sunday.

item.title: Notre-Dame Shines, and World Gets a Sneak Peek, on Macron’s Televised Tour
item.description: “You’ve achieved what was said to be impossible,” the French president told workers at the Paris monument, which will reopen after the 2019 fire.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Christophe Petit Tesson
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron of France during a visit to Notre-Dame Cathedral in Paris on Friday.

item.title: Israel Warns Residents on Both Sides of Lebanon Border to Stay Away
item.description: The cease-fire appeared to largely be holding, but it was unclear when hundreds of thousands of Lebanese and tens of thousands of Israelis could return to their homes near the border.
item.dc:creator: Liam Stack and Euan Ward
item.media:description: Damage in a neighborhood of Tyre, Lebanon, as residents continued to return to their homes on Friday.

item.title: Russia Moves to Cut Off Ukraine’s Nuclear Power Plants
item.description: Moscow has increasingly hit critical substations linked to nuclear power plants in an effort to disconnect them. At the same time, Ukraine replaced the commander of its ground forces.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:description: Repairing a power line on Friday outside Odesa, Ukraine, after a Russian drone strike.

item.title: After Lebanon Cease-Fire, Gaza and Iran’s Nuclear Ambitions Await Trump
item.description: A broader peace in the Middle East will be difficult to achieve, and Iran’s threat to Israel looms over any diplomatic effort.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: A billboard depicting Iranian scientists making the Fattah-1, Iran’s first hypersonic ballistic missile, in downtown Tehran, Iran, on Tuesday.

item.title: Life After Death: America’s Cemeteries Are Rewilding
item.description: More burial sites are forgoing pristine lawns for drought resistant plants and wildflowers that help wildlife. Efforts picked up in the pandemic.
item.dc:creator: Cara Buckley
item.media:credit: Bing Guan for The New York Times
item.media:description: Green-Wood Cemetery in Brooklyn is among the earliest cemeteries in the country to be modeled after rural landscapes, and to serve as an urban park.

item.title: Death of Cyclist in Paris Lays Bare Divide in Mayor’s War Against Cars
item.description: Paul Varry was run over on a city street in what prosecutors suspect was a deliberate act of road rage, as bikers and drivers choose sides.
item.dc:creator: Richard Fausset and Ségolène Le Stradic
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: Cyclists waiting for a green light on a bridge over the Seine in June.

item.title: Here Are the Risks When Zoos Pay for Endangered Species
item.description: We tracked $86 million in U.S. money that was supposed to go toward panda conservation in China.
item.dc:creator: Mara Hvistendahl
item.media:credit: Ariana Drehsler for The New York Times
item.media:description: Yun Chuan, a male, at the San Diego Zoo in August. American zoos have come to count on pandas, which attract unparalleled crowd numbers, merchandise sales and media attention.

item.title: Millions of Dollars to Protect Pandas Was Spent by China on Roads and Buildings
item.description: A Times investigation found that zoos knew conservation money went toward apartment buildings and roads. But they wanted to keep displaying pandas, so nobody looked too closely.
item.dc:creator: Mara Hvistendahl
item.media:credit: Ariana Drehsler for The New York Times
item.media:description: A female panda, Xin Bao, at the San Diego Zoo in August.

item.title: Ukraine’s River of Anguish
item.description: Amphibious operations across the Dnipro River at Kherson illustrated the suffering and endurance of Ukrainian forces. A team of Times journalists observed the perilous movements.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall, Oleksandr Chubko and Mauricio Lima
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Members of the 126th Territorial Defense Brigrade rested in a fortified front line position after returning from a night mission on the banks of the Dnipro River.

item.title: China Journalist, Dong Yuyu, Is Sentenced to Prison for Espionage
item.description: Dong Yuyu, who has written articles critical of the Communist Party, was arrested in 2022 while having lunch with a Japanese diplomat.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang
item.media:description: Dong Yuyu at Harvard University in 2017. He built his career when the Chinese government encouraged interaction with foreigners, but such contacts are now viewed with extreme suspicion.

item.title: Friday Briefing
item.description: The cease-fire between Israel and Hezbollah.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost

item.title: A Dublin Neighborhood at the Sharp End of Ireland’s Election Issues
item.description: In a northeast neighborhood of the capital city, deprivation and affluence exist side-by-side, and many voters feel frustrated by the status quo.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Paulo Nunes dos Santos for The New York Times
item.media:description: Campaign posters hanging on lamp posts and the facade of a derelict building on Sean McDermott Street in northeast inner-city Dublin, Ireland, on Nov. 27. In a recent election poll, Ireland’s three major parties, Fianna Fáil, Fine Gael and Sinn Féin, were neck-and-neck, with 21 percent, 20 percent and 19 percent, respectively.

item.title: Why Mexico Is Eliminating Independent Watchdog Agencies
item.description: A vote in the country’s Senate has cleared the way to abolish seven independent organizations that provided oversight on issues such as public information and price fixing.
item.dc:creator: James Wagner and Emiliano Rodríguez Mega
item.media:description: A protest in Mexico City last year in support of Mexico’s freedom of information body, known as INAI, after the president at the time, Andrés Manuel López Obrador, backed a proposal to scrap it.

item.title: Canada Accuses Google of Creating Advertising Tech Monopoly
item.description: The case largely echoes an antitrust action in the United States and seeks to force Google to sell off sections of its online ad business.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:description: Canada’s competition authority said that Google owned four of the largest online advertising tech services in the country and that they control 40 percent to 90 percent of their market.

item.title: Friday Briefing: Day 2 of Lebanon’s Cease-fire
item.description: Plus, the gangs stealing hiring exams in India.
item.dc:creator: Gaya Gupta
item.media:description: Residents driving past a mosque in southern Lebanon, yesterday.

item.title: Lebanese Residents of Baalbek Return to a Bombed-Out City
item.description: Tens of thousands of people who had fled the city of Baalbek returned to bombed-out restaurants, flattened apartment buildings and many of the dead still buried under the rubble.
item.dc:creator: Euan Ward
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: The ancient city of Baalbek, Lebanon, has been bombed and many buildings flattened.

item.title: Hiker Survives 50 Days in Canadian Wilderness
item.description: Sam Benastick was found after weeks missing in British Columbia’s frigid Redfern-Keily Provincial Park, and after the official search was called off. The police had feared “this would not be the outcome,” a spokeswoman said.
item.dc:creator: Eve Sampson

item.title: Romania Court Orders a Recount After Surprise Election Result
item.description: A top court issued the ruling just days after an ultranationalist outsider unexpectedly won the most votes in the first round of presidential elections held Sunday.
item.dc:creator: Matei Barbulescu and Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:description: Calin Georgescu, who won the most votes in the first round, speaking to reporters on Tuesday in Izvorani, Romania.

item.title: Daniel Khalife, UK Prison Escapee, Is Convicted of Spying for Iran
item.description: Daniel Khalife also pleaded guilty to an escape from a London jail, strapped underneath a truck with a sling made of trousers, that embarrassed the British authorities.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: A police van believed to be transporting former soldier Daniel Khalife leaving Westminster Magistrates Court in London in September 2023.

item.title: Bangladesh Ties with India Plunge Further After Arrest of Hindu Leader
item.description: India and Bangladesh have traded angry accusations about Bangladesh’s Hindu minority.
item.dc:creator: Saif Hasnat, Anupreeta Das and Mujib Mashal
item.media:description: Chinmoy Krishna Das, a Hindu leader in Bangladesh, has been accused of sedition under a colonial-era law.

item.title: What Rebels’ Offensive in Syria Means for a Stalled Civil War
item.description: Rebel groups have launched the largest offensive in years against government forces, capturing the city of Aleppo.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim
item.category: National Coalition of Syrian Revolutionary and Opposition Forces
item.media:description: Rebel fighters on Thursday in Aleppo Province, in Syria’s north.
